attraction.title: Wollman Rink
attraction.description: Skating on Wollman Rink is a winter tradition in New York. Many people have tied up their skates for the very first time on this ice.

attraction.title: Wollman Refreshments
attraction.description: Skating on Wollman Rink is a winter tradition for New Yorkers and tourists alike – so many people have tied up their skates for the very first time on this very ice.

attraction.title: Wisteria Pergola
attraction.description: The Wisteria Pergola features century-old wisteria vines attached to a wooden shelter that is reminiscent of the original that was designed by Calvert Vaux. It was created as a cool refuge from summer sun, and as an overlook to the music concerts below at the original Bandstand.

attraction.title: Winterdale Arch
attraction.description: Carrying the West Drive at 81st Street, this granite and sandstone arch was a key feature of the Winter Drive, the conifer-lined West Drive from 102nd street to 72nd Street.

attraction.title: Willowdell Arch
attraction.description: This sandstone-and-brick arch stands at the East Drive between the Mall and Fifth Avenue and leads visitors to the bronze statue of Balto, the celebrated Alaskan sled dog.

attraction.title: William Thomas Stead
attraction.description: This memorial plaque to the renowned British journalist is affixed to the Park’s eastern perimeter wall, not far from Engineer’s Gate.

attraction.title: William Tecumseh Sherman
attraction.description: The sculpture of General William Tecumseh Sherman is one of the finest sculptures by the talented American sculptor and New York City resident Augustus St.Gaudens.

attraction.title: William Shakespeare
attraction.description: William Shakespeare was the first sculpture of a writer to be placed on the Mall, known informally as Literary Walk.

attraction.title: Wild West Playground
attraction.description: This western-themed playground features wooden play structures resembling a frontier town.

attraction.title: Wien Walk
attraction.description: Wien Walk is one of the most heavily traveled entrance paths into Central Park. at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street. It provides access to the Park for thousands of visitors.

attraction.title: West 77th Street Stone Arch
attraction.description: The Park's only double arch, this stone structure carries an access road to the West Drive from Central Park West over both the bridle path and a pedestrian path.

attraction.title: West 110th Street Playground
attraction.description: This playground is set in a small valley surrounded by large trees and rock outcrops – the dramatic topography that characterizes the northern part of Central Park.

attraction.title: Waldo Hutchins Bench
attraction.description: Southeast of Conservatory Water is a curved white granite bench dedicated to Waldo Hutchins, a member of the original Board of Commissioners for Central Park.

attraction.title: Wagner Cove
attraction.description: Wagner Cove is one of Central Park's hidden oases of calm. Tucked away into a shady corner of the Lake, the Cove features a small rustic wood shelter.

attraction.title: Volleyball Courts
attraction.description: Volleyball courts are available for play during warmer weather months.

attraction.title: Volleyball
attraction.description: Pickup volleyball games can be played year-round at courts on a first-come, first-served basis within Central Park.

attraction.title: Vista Rock
attraction.description: The highest point in Central Park, Vista Rock is a massive outcropping of schist from which Belvedere Castle stands. The National Weather Service has measured temperatures from this spot since 1919.

attraction.title: Victorian Gardens Amusement Park
attraction.description: As the summer operation of Wollman Rink, this whimsical family amusement park features twelve hand-crafted rides that are sure to delight all guests.

attraction.title: Victor Herbert
attraction.description: This bronze portrait bust commemorates the renowned Irish-American composer and conductor. It stands appropriately near the site of his countless memorable performances on the Park's concert ground.

attraction.title: Vanderbilt Gate
attraction.description: The entrance of Conservatory Garden, Vanderbilt Gate is considered one of the finest examples of wrought iron work in New York City.

attraction.title: Untermyer Fountain
attraction.description: The sculpture came to Central Park in 1947 after the death of Samuel Untermyer. It is a cast of the original. Just how Untermyer acquired the sculpture from the Berlin original or had the cast made remains a mystery.

attraction.title: Umpire Rock
attraction.description: One of the best examples of Central Park's rich endowment of exposed bedrock, Umpire Rock is likely named for its commanding view of nearby baseball diamonds.

attraction.title: Turtle Pond
attraction.description: Like all of the other water bodies in Central Park, Turtle Pond is man-made, filled with New York City drinking water. It is the home to five species of turtles who live in the Pond year round.

attraction.title: Trefoil Arch
attraction.description: This ornamental archway made of brownstone is unique in that its east and west side walls have distinctly different looks. It is named for its signature feature, the three-lobe patterned arch on its east side.

attraction.title: Tours
attraction.description: For first time visitors and seasoned New Yorkers alike, Official Central Park Tours are the best way to enhance your visit. Our expert guides highlight the Park’s history and design, horticulture and maintenance, and amazing story of this American masterpiece.

attraction.title: Thomas Moore
attraction.description: This bronze bust of the Irish poet stands on the eastern edge of the Pond. Moore was considered the national bard of Ireland in the early 19th century.

attraction.title: The Tempest
attraction.description: This is one of two life-size sculptures from Shakespeare's plays that stand at the entrance to the Delacorte Theatre.

attraction.title: The Ravine
attraction.description: When Park designers Olmsted and Vaux created this area of the Park, they envisioned an urban escape where visitors could come and appreciate the wonders of nature.

attraction.title: The Ramble
attraction.description: A thriving wildlife habitat, the Ramble is the center of birding activity in the Park. Over 230 species migrate through, and over 40 others remain in the Park year round.

attraction.title: The Ramble
attraction.description: A thriving wildlife habitat, the Ramble is the center of birding activity in the Park. Over 230 species migrate through, and over 40 others remain in the Park year round.

attraction.title: The Pool
attraction.description: With its grassy banks, weeping willows, and rushing waterfall, the Pool is one of the most idyllic spots in the Park.

attraction.title: The Pond
attraction.description: The Pond is one of Central Park's seven naturalistic water bodies. When Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux designed Central Park, they imagined an immediate reprieve from the City's streets and designed the Pond as a serene escape, just feet from Fifth Avenue. Despite the millions of visitors who walk by the water's edge each year, you can still find a sense of solitude.

attraction.title: The Point
attraction.description: The Point is a verdant peninsula in the Ramble that juts into the Lake. It offers visitors a beautiful vantage point from which to view Bethesda Terrace to the south and Bow Bridge to the west.

attraction.title: The Pilgrim
attraction.description: On the occasion of the New England Society's 75th anniversary, the association commissioned the statue to honor America's earliest colonists.

attraction.title: The Mount
attraction.description: Before the construction of Central Park in 1857, this area was the site of a convent and school run by the Sisters of Charity of Mount St. Vincent, constructed in 1848. Today, this area is the site of the Conservancy's composting operation.

attraction.title: The Mall and Literary Walk
attraction.description: The Mall, a quadruple row of American elms, is Central Park's most important horticultural feature, and one of the largest and last remaining stands of American Elm trees in North America.

attraction.title: The Loch
attraction.description: Winding through the Ravine, the Loch, Scottish for "lake," is partially fed by a natural watercourse, known in the 17th and 18th centuries as Montayne's Rivulet.

attraction.title: The Lake
attraction.description: The 20-acre Lake is the second largest of Central Park's man-made water bodies.

attraction.title: The Falconer
attraction.description: The sculpture depicts both a human figure, clad in Elizabethan dress, and a falcon, representing the union and communion between a bird of prey and man.

attraction.title: Tennis Courts
attraction.description: The Central Park Tennis Center offers the largest collection of public courts in the city, with twenty-six clay and four hard courts.

attraction.title: Tavern on the Green
attraction.description: Tavern on the Green restaurant was built in 1870 as the Sheepfold for the flock of sheep who grazed on the adjacent Sheep Meadow. In 1934 it was turned into a restaurant, which has seen many different owners and images in the past 80 years. The restaurant is currently under restoration and will open in the near future.

attraction.title: Tarr-Coyne Tots Playground
attraction.description: The completely rebuild Tarr-Coyne Tots Playground provides an ideal play space for the Park's youngest visitors.

attraction.title: Tarr Family Playground
attraction.description: This playground is divided by a central bridge that stretches over a "lake" of sand, creating an area for preschoolers and one geared toward older children.

attraction.title: Swimming
attraction.description: Find relief from New York's hazy, hot and humid summers with a dip in Lasker Pool.

attraction.title: Swedish Cottage
attraction.description: The Swedish Cottage is home to one of the last public marionette companies in the United States. Puppeteers have worked there since 1947.

attraction.title: Summit Rock
attraction.description: At 141.8 feet, Summit Rock is the highest natural elevation in Central Park.

attraction.title: Strawberry Fields
attraction.description: Strawberry Fields is a living memorial to the world-famous singer, songwriter and peace activist, John Lennon.

attraction.title: Still Hunt
attraction.description: Situated on a rock outcrop on the west side of the East Drive at the edge of the Ramble, the crouching bronze panther has scared many joggers as they approach this life-size and realistic representation.

attraction.title: Springbanks Arch
attraction.description: A charming stone span on the northern edge of North Meadow near the Loch, Springbanks Arch is one of the least known of Central Park's arches.

attraction.title: Sophie Loeb Fountain
attraction.description: Originally a drinking fountain dedicated to Ms. Loeb, a writer and social advocate for children, this sculpture stood outside Heckscher Playground. In 1987 it was moved by the Central Park Conservancy to the Levin Playground and refitted as a water play feature.

attraction.title: Soccer
attraction.description: Soccer can be played from mid-September through mid-November at two locations in Central Park, the North and East Meadows. Permits are required and cleats are prohibited.

attraction.title: Sir Walter Scott
attraction.description: Walter Scott (1771-1832), author of the popular novel Ivanhoe, is celebrated for his invention of the historical novel.

attraction.title: Simon Bolivar
attraction.description: Simon Bolivar (1783-1830), born in Venezuela and one of South America's greatest generals, was called El Liberator because his victories over Spaniards won independence for Bolivia.

attraction.title: Sheep Meadow
attraction.description: Although today the Park's largest lawn without ballfields features people it was originally the home to a flock of pure bred sheep from 1864 until 1934. The sheep and shepherd were housed in a fanciful Victorian building nearby, what became the famous Tavern on the Green restaurant in 1934.

attraction.title: Shakespeare Garden
attraction.description: Shakespeare Garden is a four-acre landscape is named for the famed English poet and playwright. The garden is features flowers and plants mentioned in his poems and plays, with small bronze plaques scattered throughout the garden with quotes from the Bard.

attraction.title: Seneca Village Site
attraction.description: Seneca Village may possibly have been Manhattan's first stable community of African American property owners. Located from 81st to 89th Streets between Seventh and Eighth Avenues in what is now a section of Central Park, the village is important part of the history of New York City.

attraction.title: Samuel F. B. Morse
attraction.description: This statue of the famed inventor of the wire telegraph stands at Inventor's Gate, on Fifth Avenue and 72nd Street. It is one of the only statues in the Park that memorializes the profession of the named gate (the other is Alexander Von Humboldt at Naturalists' Gate).

attraction.title: Safari Playground
attraction.description: This playground features naturalistic hippopotamus sculptures by the artist Bob Cassily, set in a "river" of blue safety surfacing.

attraction.title: Ruth and Arthur Smadbeck – Heckscher East Playground
attraction.description: This playground's focal point is the Group of Bears sculpture by renowned artist Paul Manship.

attraction.title: Rustic Overlook
attraction.description: Just off the bridle path at West 74th Street is an enclave of three rustic benches and fences that provide a place for quiet contemplation and a spectacular view of the Lake and the Ramble's western shoreline.

attraction.title: Running
attraction.description: Offering both hilly and flat terrain and a combination of surfaces, Central Park is a runner's paradise.

attraction.title: Rumsey Playfield
attraction.description: Rumsey Playfield – a hot spot for music, dance, spoken word, and film as the home of the popular SummerStage cultural series.

attraction.title: Rudin Family Playground
attraction.description: The centerpiece of this playground is a large, wisteria-covered trellis that provides shaded seating.

attraction.title: Romeo and Juliet
attraction.description: This is one of two life-size sculptures from Shakespeare's plays at the entrance to the Delacorte Theatre.

attraction.title: Rollerblading
attraction.description: Central Park's drives provide a challenging course for in-line skating. Circling the entire Park, the drives provide three long distance routes - 6.1 miles, 5.2 miles or 1.7 miles, or shorter distances if you cross the Park at a number of scenic locations

attraction.title: Robert Burns
attraction.description: Robert Burns (1759-1796), Scotland's national poet, is most famous for his song Auld Lang Syne.

attraction.title: Robert Bendheim Playground
attraction.description: A "playground for all children," this play space was designed to be accessible to children with and without disabilities.

attraction.title: Riftstone Arch
attraction.description: Arching over the Park's bridle path, Riftstone is built with blocks of Manhattan schist that had been blasted from the Park's rock outcrops.

attraction.title: Richard Morris Hunt
attraction.description: This striking, curved monument on the Park's eastern perimeter honors Richard Morris Hunt, the most prominent architect of his time.

attraction.title: Restroom
attraction.description: Restrooms are available at various locations around Central Park. Full listing available here!

attraction.title: Reservoir Running Track
attraction.description: With its inspiring view of the water and Manhattan skyline above, the 1.58 mile track looping around the 106-acre Reservoir is one of New York City's most popular running spots.

attraction.title: Reservoir
attraction.description: Built in the 1860s as a temporary water supply for New York City, the Reservoir is surrounded by a 1.58 mile running track.

attraction.title: Ramble Stone Arch
attraction.description: This rough stone arch stands in a cleft between two high rock outcrops. It is considered one of the most picturesque of Central Park's bridges.

attraction.title: Pulitzer Fountain
attraction.description: When newspaper publisher Joseph Pulitzer died in 1911, he bequeathed $50,000 "for the erection of a fountain like those in the Place de la Concorde, Paris, France." Pulitzer got the idea to locate the fountain in Grand Army Plaza from Karl Bitter, the Austrian sculptor, who proposed a symmetrical plaza for this area.

attraction.title: Pool Grotto
attraction.description: Jutting from the southwest of the Pool, this naturalistic boulder grotto is the well-concealed reminder that Central Park is entirely man-made. This naturalistic boulder grotto conceals the 48-inch pipe that feeds the Pool fresh water from the Reservoir just half a mile south.

attraction.title: Playmates Arch
attraction.description: Playmates Arch, designed by Calvert Vaux in 1863, links the Dairy and the Carousel, and its light-hearted name comes from its position in the Children's District, the area in the southern end of the Park that had many features and amenities dedicated to children.

attraction.title: Pinebank Arch
attraction.description: Pine Bank Arch is one of Central Park's seven original cast-iron bridges, and one of just five of the original remaining.

attraction.title: Pilgrim Hill
attraction.description: The knoll that rises to the southwest of Conservatory Water is known as Pilgrim Hill because of the bronze statue of a Pilgrim that crowns the crest. It is one of the best sledding spots in the Park.

attraction.title: Peter Jay Sharp Children's Glade
attraction.description: The Peter Jay Sharp Children's Glade was once an overgrown and underused area, but in 2007 the Conservancy's design team added grass glades, stone and tree trunk seating, and country paths to turn the area into a place for children to explore nature, arts and culture.

attraction.title: Osborn Gates
attraction.description: One of the most important pieces of art in the Park, the cast-bronze gates were created by renowned sculptor Paul Manship. The Conservancy refurbished the gates in 2009, and today they stand at the entrance of Ancient Playground at Fifth Avenue and 84th Street.

attraction.title: Olmsted Flower Bed
attraction.description: The flowerbed at the southern end of the Mall was created in 1972 to commemorate the 150th anniversary of Frederick Law Olmsted's birthday.

attraction.title: Obelisk
attraction.description: For the first time since 1885, the Obelisk in Central Park will undergo a comprehensive conservation treatment. The 132 years the Obelisk has stood in the Park represent a small fraction of its 3,500-year history, and this treatment will preserve it for many more years. The project is overseen by the Conservancy's Department of Planning, Design, and Construction and has involved experts from the Metropolitan Museum of Art and other institutions.

attraction.title: Oak Bridge at Bank Rock Bay
attraction.description: This footbridge crossing Bank Rock Bay was originally built of white oak — hence its early name, Oak Bridge. In 2009, the Conservancy recreated the bridge using historic photographs and original drawings.

attraction.title: Nutter's Battery Site
attraction.description: One of a string of military fortifications built atop the steep bluffs of the Harlem Meer, Nutter's Battery today offers Park visitors a stunning view of Harlem Meer.

attraction.title: North Woods
attraction.description: Perhaps the most secluded and peaceful area of Central Park, the North Woods (located at Central Park's northwest corner) offers a taste of the Adirondack Mountains just a few subway stops away from Times Square.

attraction.title: North Meadow Recreation Center
attraction.description: At the south end of Central Park's largest open space is the North Meadow Recreation Center — a hub for sports and community activities in the Park.

attraction.title: North Meadow
attraction.description: North Meadow has seven baseball and five softball fields, which become soccer and touch football fields every fall. But on a spring or summer afternoon, the fields are full of softball teams.

attraction.title: Nell Singer Lilac Walk
attraction.description: On the northern edge of Sheep Meadow, Lilac Walk boasts varieties of its signature fragrant flower from around the world. It is named for philanthropist Nell Singer, who financed its creation in 1970.

attraction.title: Naumburg Bandshell
attraction.description: At the Naumburg Bandshell on the concert ground at the northern end of the Mall, you might enjoy a variety of organized, unamplified musical events.

attraction.title: Naturalists' Walk
attraction.description: Restored in 1996, this landscape features rustic benches and an inviting meadow and rock outcrop. It is often used by visitors to the Museum of Natural History across the street

attraction.title: Mother Goose
attraction.description: Here children can see Mother Goose flying her large goose as her cape is blown upward by the wind.

attraction.title: Minton Tile Ceiling at Bethesda Terrace
attraction.description: Bethesda Terrace arcade was created in the 1860s as a part of the Park's main architectural feature. The highlight of the arcade is the magnificent Minton Tile ceiling.

attraction.title: Merchants' Gate Plaza
attraction.description: Refreshments are available at two Victorian-style kiosks on Merchants' Gate Plaza, one of the busiest entrances of Central Park.

attraction.title: McGowan's Pass
attraction.description: McGowan's Pass is one of the fortifications in the northern end of Central Park that had a role in both the American Revolution and War of 1812.

attraction.title: Mariners' Playground
attraction.description: This nautically themed playground is located just north of Summit Rock, near the Park's Mariners' Gate entrance. It provides a variety of play experiences for younger children.

attraction.title: Maine Monument
attraction.description: The Maine Monument commemorates the 260 American sailors who perished in 1898 when the battleship Maine exploded in the harbor of Havana, Cuba, then under Spanish rule.

attraction.title: Ludwig van Beethoven
attraction.description: Donated by the German-American Choir Society, the bronze bust of the German composer joined the growing collection of statuary on the Mall in 1884.

attraction.title: Lombard Lamp
attraction.description: A charming touch of old world Germany, the Lombard Lamp illuminates the nook of Central Park where a long, winding staircase leads up from the Pond to the Grand Army Plaza.

attraction.title: Loeb Boathouse Refreshments
attraction.description: At Loeb Boathouse, visitors can rent rowboats and bikes, hire an authentic Venetian gondola, or dine overlooking views of the Lake.

attraction.title: Loeb Boathouse
attraction.description: At the Loeb Boathouse, visitors can rent rowboats and bikes, hire an authentic Venetian gondola, or dine overlooking views of the Lake.

attraction.title: Levy Gate
attraction.description: Named for philanthropists Irving and Estelle Levy, this two-leaved bronze gate is ornamented with animal figures. It stands at the Pat Hoffman Friedman Playground.

attraction.title: Lehman Gates
attraction.description: Designed by Paul Manship, the sculptor of one of the more elaborate gates at the Wildlife Conservation Center in the Bronx (the Bronx Zoo), the Lehman Gates' animals birds, and boys are interwoven in a fanciful scrolling lintel.

attraction.title: Le Pain Quotidien
attraction.description: Le Pain Quotidien is the popular European cafe chain that transformed the concession building north of Sheep Meadow at Mineral Springs, serving bakery fare, healthful salads, handmade breads, and organic drinks.

attraction.title: Lawn Bowling and Croquet
attraction.description: Central Park is home to two beautiful fields for lawn bowling and croquet, each 15,000 square feet.

attraction.title: Lasker Rink and Pool
attraction.description: Lasker Rink and Pool opened in 1966 and occupies a site that destroyed one of Olmsted and Vaux's magnificent landscape experiences by blocking the views from the Loch to the Harlem Meer.

attraction.title: Ladies Pavilion
attraction.description: Ladies Pavilion is an important and charming example of 19th century American decorative arts.

attraction.title: Kite Flying
attraction.description: Kite flying is permitted without a permit anywhere in Central Park where ther are large, open landscapes away from trees.

attraction.title: King Jagiello
attraction.description: This imposing statue was originally featured at the entrance to the Polish pavilion at the 1939 World's Fair of Flushing Meadows, Queens. Later that year, the Nazis invaded Poland, preventing the sculpture's return to its homeland. In 1945, it was placed in Central Park by the Polish government as a symbol of the proud and courageous Polish people.

attraction.title: Kerbs Boathouse
attraction.description: The copper-roofed boathouse stands east of Conservatory Water, Central Park's famous model boat pond, more formally known as Conservatory Water. The building features a cafe with light refreshments and has restrooms.

attraction.title: Jose Julian Marti
attraction.description: José Julián Martí, a Cuban patriot, journalist and poet, fought for the liberation of Cuba from Spanish rule. The statue shows the moment when Martí was mortally wounded in battle.

attraction.title: Jose de San Martin
attraction.description: The monument is a smaller-scale replica cast from the original, erected in the Plaza de San Martin in Buenos Aires in 1862. It was a gift from the City of Buenos Aires to the City of New York.

attraction.title: John Purroy Mitchel
attraction.description: This granite and bronze monument is known well to runners and walkers who enter its terrace stairway to the Reservoir at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street.

attraction.title: Johann C.F. von Schiller
attraction.description: German-American citizens wished to honor their country's cultural heroes, Beethoven and Schiller, with monuments in the Park. The bust of Schiller, dramatist, poet, and philosopher, was the first sculpture to be placed in the Park.

attraction.title: James Michael Levin Playground
attraction.description: In the center of this playground at East 76th Street is a whimsical water spray fountain featuring characters from Alice in Wonderland. Play features include colorful pipe frame equipment and bucket swings and are geared toward toddlers.

attraction.title: Iphigene's Walk
attraction.description: Commemorating the life and work of a life-long Central Park advocate, preservationist, and philanthropist Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, this area of the Ramble was one of her favorite areas in the Park.

attraction.title: Inscope Arch
attraction.description: Connecting the Zoo with the Pond, Inscope is a striking example of Ruskinian Gothic architecture perfected by Park architect Jacob Wrey Mould.

attraction.title: Information Kiosk
attraction.description: Get directions, maps and information about Central Park at the Park's three information kiosks. Staffed by Conservancy volunteers, the booths are open from April through November. They are located at East 72nd Street; the intersection of the West 72nd Street and the 72nd Street cross drive; and Grand Army Plaza at 59th Street.

attraction.title: Indian Hunter
attraction.description: Indian Hunter was the first sculpture in Central Park created by an American artist, John Quincy Adams Ward.

attraction.title: Ice-Skating
attraction.description: Feel the nip of New York's crisp winter air, enjoy the music, and take in the incomparable surroundings as you ice skate at one of Central Park's ice rinks.

attraction.title: Huddlestone Arch
attraction.description: A marvel of engineering and construction, Huddlestone Arch is considered by many to be the most surprising of Central Park's arches.

attraction.title: Horse-Drawn Carriage Rental
attraction.description: Horse-drawn carriages can be found all year round lined up along Central Park South between 5th and 6th Avenues.

attraction.title: Honey Bear
attraction.description: This whimsical bronze statue is part of a pair of niche sculptures that flank the brick triple-archway between the Central Park Zoo and the Children's Zoo.

attraction.title: Hernshead
attraction.description: Hernshead, a promontory that juts out into the Lake, is named after what must have once been the shape of a "hern" or heron’s head, and a bird often sighted in Central Park. Hernshead is planted with seasonal flowers and aquatic plantings.

attraction.title: Heckscher Playground
attraction.description: When Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux designed Central Park in the 19th Century, they designated this 10-acre meadow in the southwest corner of the Park as a "playground" — the term used to describe a versatile open meadow intended for games, sports and informal play.

attraction.title: Heckscher Ballfields
attraction.description: Hundreds of baseball and softball games are played each season at the six fields that make up the newly restored Heckscher Ballfields.

attraction.title: Harlem Meer Snack Bar
attraction.description: Central Park designers Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux named this man-made water body "the Meer" — Dutch for "lake." It was a nod to the 17th Century European settlers who first inhabited the village of Harlem.

attraction.title: Harlem Meer
attraction.description: Central Park designers Olmsted and Vaux named this man-made water body "the Meer" - Dutch for "lake." It memorialized the former separate village of Harlem that was settled in the 17th Century by European settlers and included the upper regions of Central Park.

attraction.title: Hans Christian Andersen
attraction.description: Hans Christian Andersen is one of the most popular climbing sculptures in the Park.

attraction.title: Handball Courts
attraction.description: The North Meadow Recreation Center is home to 12 handball courts.

attraction.title: Hallett Nature Sanctuary
attraction.description: Wrapping around the Pond at the southeast corner of Central Park is the 4-acre Hallett Nature Sanctuary, a peaceful haven just feet away from some of the most heavily trafficked paths of any park in the world.

attraction.title: Group of Bears
attraction.description: Pat Hoffman Friedman Playground's Group of Bears statue graces the center of the playground to the delight of children.

attraction.title: Greywacke Arch
attraction.description: Greywacke Arch is named for the variety of Hudson Valley sandstone with which it is built. One of the most ornamental of the Park's arches, it is distinguished by the detail of its trefoil design and its pointed arch.

attraction.title: Greyshot Arch
attraction.description: One of the most heavily trafficked arches of Central Park, Greyshot carries a steady flow of bikers, runners, rollerbladers, and carriages over the West Drive.

attraction.title: Green Gap Arch
attraction.description: Originally serving the bridle path going toward the Scholar's Gate entrance of the Park, Green Gap Arch is now closed and part of the Central Park Zoo.

attraction.title: Great Lawn
attraction.description: This green 55-acre area is the geographical center of Central Park — and one of the most famous lawns in the world.

attraction.title: Great Hill
attraction.description: The Great Hill is an open hilltop meadow with picnic tables, a three-quarter mile soft surface oval path (good for a jog), and lawn under a ring of stately trees.

attraction.title: Grand Army Plaza
attraction.description: Grand Army Plaza is the gateway to Central Park. Of the four corners of Central Park, it’s the only one that’s officially part of the Park’s 843-acre landscape.

attraction.title: Glen Span Arch
attraction.description: Glen Span is one of two rustic arches that form the boundaries of the Ravine, the stream valley of the North Woods. It arches over the narrow water body called the Loch.

attraction.title: Glade Arch
attraction.description: Glade Arch was among Calvert Vaux's first designed bridges and arches. Constructed in 1862, it originally carried carriage traffic to Fifth Avenue. Today it provides a wide walkway for visitors.

attraction.title: Giuseppe Mazzini
attraction.description: Commissioned by an Italian-American group, this bronze bust of the Italian patriot, philosopher, and politician overlooks Sheep Meadow.

attraction.title: Gill Rustic Bridge
attraction.description: Azalea Pond is fed by a tumbling stream called the Gill, which has its own rustic bridge, complete with benches for admiring the beautiful azalea blooms in the spring.

attraction.title: Gill
attraction.description: A tumbling stream that cuts through the Ramble, the Gill trickles down a rocky slope before spilling into the Lake. It is a unique habitat and a favorite nook for birding.

attraction.title: Gapstow Bridge
attraction.description: Curving gracefully over the neck of the Pond at 59th Street, Gapstow is one of the iconic bridges of Central Park. It is the second bridge in its place. The first, a much more elaborate wood and iron bridge, designed by Jacob Wrey Mould, deteriorated and was replaced in 1896.

attraction.title: Frederick Douglass
attraction.description: Frederick Douglass Circle was named for the great African-American leader in 1950.

attraction.title: Fort Fish
attraction.description: One of a string of military fortifications built atop the steep bluffs of the Harlem Meer, Fort Fish today stands as an open green field cut by a single path. It is also home to the Andrew Haswell Green bench.

attraction.title: Fort Clinton
attraction.description: One of a string of military fortifications built atop the steep bluffs overlooking the Harlem Meer, Fort Clinton today offers Park visitors a stunning view of the Harlem Meer.

attraction.title: Football
attraction.description: Touch football and flag football can be played at the North Meadow from mid-September through mid-November. Permits are required and cleats are prohibited.

attraction.title: Fitz-Greene Halleck
attraction.description: The least known literary figure today on the mall, Halleck was a writer of satirical and romantic verse, and for many years the personal secretary to the eminent John Jacob Astor.

attraction.title: Fishing at the Harlem Meer
attraction.description: Catch-and-release fishing at the Harlem Meer has become a favorite community pastime in Central Park, and the Meer has become the has preferred fishing area in the Park. Free equipment and appropriate bait are available.

attraction.title: East Meadow
attraction.description: This pastoral meadow just off of Fifth Avenue is a popular spot for events and recreation.

attraction.title: East Green
attraction.description: Visitors in search of a tranquil area to relax on a lawn can head to East Green, one of eight designated Quiet Zones in Central Park.

attraction.title: East 96th Street Playground
attraction.description: One of Central Park's largest playgrounds, the East 96th Street Playground features a great variety of play equipment and ample open space for running and playing games.

attraction.title: East 72nd Street Playground
attraction.description: This playground's low concrete walls and numerous steps and seats define the play space, as well as providing a variety of levels and surfaces to climb and explore.

attraction.title: East 110th Street Playground
attraction.description: Located across from the Harlem Meer, Central Park's northernmost playground has been completely rebuilt by the Conservancy in 2013, featuring the latest in playground design.

attraction.title: Eagles and Prey
attraction.description: This bronze sculpture is well known for the fine detail of the animals' textures — in this case the feathers of the eagles and the woolly coat of the goat.

attraction.title: Duke Ellington
attraction.description: This sculpture is the first monument in New York City dedicated to an African American and the first memorial to Duke Ellington in the United States.

attraction.title: Driprock Arch
attraction.description: Driprock Arch originally stood over the bridle path that was destroyed with the expansion of Heckscher Playground in the 1930s.

attraction.title: Dr. J. Marion Sims
attraction.description: Dedicated in 1894, this bronze and granite monument standing on the Park perimeter memorializes the surgeon J. Marion Sims, regarded as the father of American gynecology.

attraction.title: Doris C. Freedman Plaza
attraction.description: The Doris C. Freedman Plaza is home to rotating installations, courtesy of the city's Public Art Fund.

attraction.title: Discovery Kit
attraction.description: Borrow a Discovery Kit for an in-Park adventure! These rugged backpacks are filled with kid-friendly binoculars, field guides, a hand lens, and sketch paper.

attraction.title: Dipway Arch
attraction.description: Set beneath the Park Drive and measuring more than 15 feet wide, Dipway Arch's underpass leads around Heckscher Playground and north toward the Carousel.

attraction.title: Diana Ross Playground
attraction.description: Funding for this playground was provided by the singer Diana Ross after her historic concert on the Great Lawn in 1983.

attraction.title: Denesmouth Arch
attraction.description: One of Calvert Vaux's earliest arches, Denesmouth supports the 65th Street Transverse and it is the only Transverse Arch that is highly ornamented.

attraction.title: Dene
attraction.description: The Dene is a long stretch of eastside landscape that exemplifies both the design features and the intended effect of Olmsted's pastoral vision. It offers gently rolling lawns and shaded walks.

attraction.title: Delacorte Theater
attraction.description: The Delacorte Theater is the summer home of the Public Theater. Each season, more than 100,000 people from across the country, and around the world, enjoy free performances at this open-air theater.

attraction.title: Delacorte Clock
attraction.description: Named after philanthropist George T. Delacorte, the clock brings seasonal chimes and nursery rhymes on the half hour. It is one of the most popular features in Central Park.

attraction.title: Daniel Webster
attraction.description: In the 1870s, this larger-than-life-size version of the stateman was comissioned for Central Park. It proved too large for placement on the Mall as originally intended and was subsequently installed on the West Drive.

attraction.title: Dancing Goat
attraction.description: This whimsical bronze statue is part of a pair of niche sculptures that flank the buildings in the Central Park Zoo.

attraction.title: Dancing Crane Cafe
attraction.description: Featuring a wide variety of meals, snacks, and beverages for both Park and Zoo visitors. Indoor and outdoor seating.

attraction.title: Dalehead Arch
attraction.description: Dalehead Arch carries the West Drive over the bridle path that leads westward to the Heckscher Ballfields.

attraction.title: Dairy Visitor Center and Gift Shop
attraction.description: As one of the Conservancy's five visitor centers, Parkgoers can find information on Park events and programs at the Dairy. Maps, guides, and gifts are also available, all of which support the Conservancy's mission.

attraction.title: Cross-Country Skiing
attraction.description: Central Park is a wonderful venue for cross-country skiing.

attraction.title: Cop Cot
attraction.description: Cop Cot, which may means "little cottage on the crest of the hill" in Scottish is Central Park's largest wooden rustic structure.

attraction.title: Conservatory Water
attraction.description: This area is popular with families and children because of the famous climbing sculptures, the story-telling programs, the model boats, the cafe and the site in the children's classic Stuart Little.

attraction.title: Conservatory Garden Center Fountain
attraction.description: With its elegant geyser fountain standing before a wrought-iron wisteria pergola, the Italian-designed Center Garden is an enchanting spot.

attraction.title: Conservatory Garden
attraction.description: The Conservatory Garden is Central Park's six-acre formal garden. It is divided into three smaller gardens, each with a distinct style: Italian, French, and English.

attraction.title: Concerts
attraction.description: Central Park hosts concerts during the spring, summer and fall, ranging from small classical quartets at the Naumburg Bandshell to large rock concerts on the Great Lawn.

attraction.title: Christopher Columbus
attraction.description: 1892 was marked by celebrations of the 400th anniversary of Columbus's arrival in the Americas and to commemorate the event, Italians funded the dedication of Gaetano Russo's Columbus Circle stone monument on the perimeter of Central Park. Another statue of Columbus, by Spanish sculptor Jeronimo Sunol was unveiled on May 12, 1894 on the Mall.

attraction.title: Chess & Checkers House
attraction.description: The Chess & Checkers House is one of five Park visitor centers run by the Central Park Conservancy. Chess and Checkers players are welcome to borrow pieces from the Conservancy staff, or bring their own. Dominos and backgammon are also available.

attraction.title: Cherry Hill Fountain
attraction.description: This fountain at the crest of Cherry Hill is centered at what was once a scenic turn-around for carriages. This Victorian fountain originally served as a watering trough for horses.

attraction.title: Cherry Hill
attraction.description: A gentle slope overlooking the Lake with views to the Ramble, Cherry Hill offers a contemplative space perfect for picnicking, reading, and sunbathing.

attraction.title: Charles B. Stover Bench
attraction.description: Called the "Whisper Bench," the 20-foot granite memorial curls inward at each side. Whisper into one end, and it actually travels to the other side.

attraction.title: Charles A. Dana Discovery Center
attraction.description: The Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, created in 1993 by Central Park Conservancy, opened to the public in 1993 and offers a wide variety of Conservancy-sponsored free education and community programs, seasonal exhibits and holiday celebrations.

attraction.title: Central Park Zoo
attraction.description: Central Park's new, state-of-the-art Zoo was built when the Wildlife Conservation Society took over the management in 1984. It showcases animals from tropical, temperate, and polar zones around the world.

attraction.title: Central Park Police Precinct
attraction.description: The Central Park Police Precinct, the oldest precinct in the city, operates from a horse stable designed by Jacob Wrey Mould in 1871.

attraction.title: Central Park Conservancy
attraction.description: Central Park Conservancy raises 75% of Central Park's annual Parkwide expense budget and is responsible for the day to day maintenance and operations that keep the Park beautiful and vibrant.

attraction.title: Cedar Hill
attraction.description: Cedar Hill is a steep hillside meadow that ends in a shallow green valley. It is an ideal spot for passive Park activities such as picnicking, reading and sunbathing, and in winter one of the Park's most popular sledding hills.

attraction.title: Carousel
attraction.description: The famed Carousel, with its sweet calliope music and 57 magnificent horses, is the fourth to stand in Central Park since 1871. It is one of Central Park's most popular attractions.

attraction.title: Burnett Fountain
attraction.description: This statuary fountain stands in the center of the Conservatory Garden's South Garden, a memorial tribute to children's writer Frances Hodgson Burnett.

attraction.title: Bridge No. 28
attraction.description: Often called "Gothic Bridge" because of its reference to Gothic design, it is officially known as Bridge No. 28 and was designed in 1864.

attraction.title: Bridge No. 27
attraction.description: One of the three decorative cast-iron bridges that spans the bridle path near the 86th Street Transverse road.

attraction.title: Bridge No. 24
attraction.description: One of the oldest examples of cast iron bridges in America, Bridge No. 24 is located near the south gate house of the Reservoir and spans the Bridle Path. It was restored by the Central Park Conservancy in 1989, and again in 2012.

attraction.title: Bow Bridge
attraction.description: The first cast-iron bridge in the Park (and the second oldest in America), the bridge is named for its graceful shape, reminiscent of the bow of an archer or violinist.

attraction.title: Boating
attraction.description: Boating on the Lake, Central Park's second largest water body, is a great way to spend a lazy summer afternoon in the Park.

attraction.title: Bloom Guide - Test
attraction.description: Discover the horticultural beauty of Central Park with the Central Park Conservancy Bloom Guide!

attraction.title: Bloom Guide
attraction.description: Discover the horticultural beauty of Central Park with the Central Park Conservancy Bloom Guide!

attraction.title: Blockhouse
attraction.description: Central Park's oldest building, the Blockhouse is the only remaining fortification of the many built in 1814 to defend against the British. It stands on the edge of a high precipice called “The Cliff.”

attraction.title: Birding
attraction.description: Approximately 230 different species of birds can be found in Central Park during the year with some birds living in the Park year round and several species making an important stopover to rest and feed during spring and fall migrations.

attraction.title: Billy Johnson Playground
attraction.description: This playground's design was inspired by the landscapes of Central Park, making it one of the Park's most distinctive play spaces.

attraction.title: Bicycling
attraction.description: With its scenic views and hilly terrain, the Central Park Drives provide cyclists with a relaxing ride or a challenging workout, depending on the cyclist's interest.

attraction.title: Bicycle Rental
attraction.description: Bicycles for riding in Central Park are available for rent at the Loeb Central Park Boathouse daily, April through November.

attraction.title: Bethesda Terrace
attraction.description: Park designers Olmsted and Vaux envisioned a Promenade that led to a grand terrace overlooking the Lake. The carvings represent the four seasons and, on the side facing the Mall, the times of day.

attraction.title: Bethesda Fountain
attraction.description: Rising from Bethesda Terrace is Bethesda Fountain, with the famous Angel of the Waters statue atop. The statue references the Gospel of John, which describes an angel blessing the Pool of Bethesda and giving it healing powers.

attraction.title: Bernard Family Playground
attraction.description: Located in one of the most beautiful settings in the Park — across from the Harlem Meer — the playground is also near the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, which offers additional recreational opportunities.

attraction.title: Belvedere Castle
attraction.description: Calvert Vaux created the miniature castle in 1869 as one of its many whimsical structures intended as a lookout to the reservoir to the north (now the Great Lawn) and the Ramble to the south.

attraction.title: Basketball
attraction.description: Whether you are in for a pick-up game, or just want to practice your hook shot, you can come to Central Park to play basketball.

attraction.title: Baseball
attraction.description: Central Park offers a total of 26 baseball and softball fields located in three specific areas.

attraction.title: Bank Rock Bay
attraction.description: The narrow inlet of water at the northern tip of the Lake, Bank Rock Bay is a popular bird-watching area that lies just beyond Oak Bridge. In 2008, Central Park Conservancy restored the site as part of a larger effort to secure the Lake's eroding shoreline.

attraction.title: Balto
attraction.description: This sculpture honors the sled dog who saved Alaska's children from a diphtheria epidemic by delivering medicine over the frozen tundra.

attraction.title: Ballplayers' House Refreshments
attraction.description: Enjoy salads, sandwiches, burgers and other ballpark snacks at this eatery on the northern edge of the Heckscher Ballfields.

attraction.title: Balcony Bridge
attraction.description: Supporting the West Drive, this stately stone structure spans a small inlet connecting the Lake and what was originally the Ladies Pond, now Naturalists' Walk. It is named for the two bench-lined balconies on its east side.

attraction.title: Azalea Walk
attraction.description: Just south under Eaglevale Arch, Azalea Walk blooms in the springtime with a colorful variety of azaleas and rhododendrons.

attraction.title: Azalea Pond Rustic Bridge
attraction.description: This rustic bridge, created by Conservancy craftsmen, spans Azalea Pond and the Gill that flows down to the Lake.

attraction.title: Azalea Pond
attraction.description: Azalea Pond gets its name from the century-old azalea plants that crown its southern edge. Restored by the Conservancy in 2004, it is one of the most active bird-watching spots in the Park.

attraction.title: Arthur Ross Pinetum Playground
attraction.description: This playground is located within the Arthur Ross Pinetum, a small arboretum that is home to the largest collection of pine trees in the Park.

attraction.title: Arthur Ross Pinetum
attraction.description: The Arthur Ross Pinetum is a four-acre landscape that features 17 different species of pine trees.

attraction.title: Arthur Brisbane
attraction.description: This stone memorial at the Park's perimeter wall features an engraved profile of the renowned American newspaper editor and an adjacent curved granite bench.

attraction.title: Arsenal
attraction.description: The Arsenal was built between 1847 and 1851 as a munitions supply depot for New York State’s National Guard. That original military use would be short-lived, as it soon became part of Central Park.

attraction.title: Andrew Haswell Green bench
attraction.description: Dedicated to the "Father of New York City," this stone bench offers a tranquil spot for reflection in the open greenery of Fort Fish. While perhaps an unfamiliar name to many, Green played a pivotal role in the creation of Central Park.

attraction.title: Ancient Playground
attraction.description: Just north of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this playground and its climbing pyramids, obelisk, and sundial were inspired by the museum's collection of Egyptian Art.

attraction.title: Alice in Wonderland
attraction.description: The Alice in Wonderland sculpture is a favorite among children, who love to climb atop it and explore its varied textures and hiding spaces.

attraction.title: Alexander von Humboldt
attraction.description: This bronze bust depicts German scientist and naturalist Frederick Heinrich Alexander von Humboldt. It was dedicated in Central Park in 1869.

attraction.title: Alexander Hamilton
attraction.description: Carved entirely of granite, this larger-than-life-size statue was donated to Central Park in 1880 by the eminent statesman’s son, John C. Hamilton.

attraction.title: Albert Bertel Thorvaldsen
attraction.description: This bronze sculpture is a posthumous replica of a marble self-portrait carved by the famed Danish sculptor. It is the only statue of an artist displayed in a New York City park.

attraction.title: Adventure Playground
attraction.description: Short concrete walls enclose the play area of this playground, linking play equipment while also functioning as a maze and seating area.

attraction.title: Abraham and Joseph Spector Playground
attraction.description: Spector Playground is one of the largest playgrounds in the Park. It features an expansive sand area and open space for running and playing.

attraction.title: 7th Regiment Memorial
attraction.description: This statue honors the 58 men of the 7th Regiment who died defending the Union during the Civil War.

attraction.title: 110th St. Bridge
attraction.description: Carrying traffic from Central Park West to the West Drive, the stone structure was one of a third wave of bridges that came to the Upper West Side of the Park in the 1890s.

attraction.title: 107th United States Infantry
attraction.description: One of the several war memorials in Central Park, this monument is dedicated to those soldiers who served and died in World War I.
